issue.title: Adding itch.io Baba Is You error: "Access to https://api.itch.io/games/None denied"
issue.body:
### Bug description

Installed the flatpak version on fedora 38.
Trying to add a game from itch.io (Baba is you).


### How to Reproduce

Search for Baba Is You in the app.
Choose itch.io.
After choosing install directory, when clicking continue an error dialog box appears.
"Access to https://api.itch.io/games/None denied".
Unable to continue.


### Expected behavior

Move on with the install of the game.

### Log output

```shell
bash: lutris: command not found...
Install package 'lutris' to provide command 'lutris'? [N/y] n


User's notes: I'm using the flatpak version so lutris is not in my path.
```

comment.body:
One thing i want to add, just because i forgot about it.
I'm using a script to call some games with their game id, for some daily login stuff. To speed things up i always got an Lutris window open, so it won't get started and closed with every game.
I just forgot that his script uses the Flatpak version of Lutris to start the games. This still works, at least i can start games over the cli with the Flatpak version while using the game id of the game. It will show me the above mentioned error and some game related warnings and i'll have to strg+c out after the game finishes but i can start and play the game.
But the noticeable part is that i installed the native version (5.13-8) along side with the Flatpak version of Lutris, because of the problem. With the native version up and running i can start games with their id, even while calling _net.lutris.Lutris_ , and won't get any error messages except the one about fluidsynth.

issue.title: Lutris Flatpak -- Disc "Autodetect" fails
issue.body:
### Bug description

This is really three different, but tangentially related issues:

Specific to Lutris Flatpak:

- Disc "Autodetect" fails for mounted disc image.

Not specific to Flatpak:

- If "Autodetect" fails, one can only press "Back". If one then presses "Continue" (second instance), the "Install or mount game disc [...]" dialogue does not re-appear as it should, but instead the install process tries to proceed with next steps, I.e. trying to copy files from `$DISC` path (which at this point is not set!).

Unsure if specific to Flatpak:

- "Eject" seems to simply eject the first available disc drive. This misses the mark in the case of multiple disc drives, or even mounted disc images, being present.

Aside: I tested the latest GitHub master and found the following:

- "Eject" causes Lutris to lock up (mind you, I'm running from within a toolbx/Podman environment).

- Disc "Autodetect" succeeds for mounted disc image.

### How to Reproduce

Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Mount a disc image.
2. Create a basic script with at least the following `installer` parameters: `insert-disc`, `merge`. Optionally: `insert-disc` -> `requires` should reference a non-existent file on said mounted disc (triggers second bug on non-Flatpak installs).
3. Run install script with Lutris Flatpak.
4. Press "Eject" and notice behaviour (third bug).
5. Try Disc "Autodetect". Notice it fails (first bug).
6. Press "Back", then "Continue". Notice that the "Install or mount game disc [...]" dialogue does not reappear, as it should (second bug). Instead, installer will attempt to `merge` the file from non-existent `$DISC` path.

### Expected behavior

1. Ideally, "Autodetect" should work within Flatpak, just like it does on a regular install. Else, it should disable "Autodetect" button and notify user of this limitation.

2. The "Install or mount game disc [...]" should reappear, thus maintaining the desired linear nature of the install process.

3. "Eject" button should have an associated drop-down button to specify a non-default drive/mounted disc image.

### Log output

```shell

DEBUG    2023-10-25 13:57:16,946 [interpreter._iter_commands:349]:Installer command: {'insert-disc': {'requires': '<testfile.ext>'}}

# After pressing "Autodetect":

# [no output]

# (Cont.) After pressing "Back", then "Continue":

DEBUG    2023-10-25 13:58:28,015 [installerwindow.on_extras_ready:562]:Installer doesn't require files
DEBUG    2023-10-25 13:58:28,016 [interpreter._iter_commands:349]:Installer command: {'merge': {'src': '$DISC/<testfile.ext>', 'dst': '$GAMEDIR/drive_c'}}
DEBUG    2023-10-25 13:58:28,060 [commands.merge:272]:Merging $DISC/<testfile.ext> into <gamedir>
ERROR    2023-10-25 13:58:28,060 [errors.__init__:18]:Source does not exist: $DISC/<testfile.ext>
# [...]
```


### System Information

```shell
[System]
OS:              GNOME 45 Flatpak runtime
Arch:            x86_64
Kernel:          6.5.6-100.fc37.x86_64
Desktop:         GNOME
Display Server:  wayland

[CPU]
Vendor:          AuthenticAMD
Model:           AMD Ryzen 5 2600X Six-Core Processor
Physical cores:  6
Logical cores:   12

[Memory]
```

The rest open correctly.
I have checked and the file exists.

issue.title: lutris doesn’t handle relative paths properly
issue.body:
### Bug description

with recent big update, all game configs were updated/refreshed, 

all /home/deck paths were converted to ~

but after the conversion, lutris fails to handle the relative path conversion which results in a “no such file or directory” error

game config still reads /home/deck but config files contain the relative path

after a config re-save, configs save path to file as /home/deck

### How to Reproduce

Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. update lutris
2. try to launch game
3. get error


### Expected behavior

lutris should recognize the relative path for ~ to the user’s home directory

### Log output

```shell
no log required
```


### System Information

```shell
steam deck lutris flatpak
```


### Media (optional)

_No response_

### Checklist:

- [X] I'm not asking for support with a game or the wine runner.
- [X] I have followed the above mentioned guides and have all the graphics and wine dependencies installed.
- [X] I have checked for existing issues that describe my problem prior to opening this one.
- [X] I understand that improperly formatted bug reports may be closed without explanation.

comment.body:
for the time being, the easiest fix besides going into every config file.

if you get the error. in GUI, go into the game config and add (if none) or remove (if present) a "/" (without quotes)  at the end of the prefix directory and saving. it's redundant, but it will force a config file update.

example

launching game causing error, but config file reads
~/prefix/test

but in lutris GUI config it still shows full path
/home/deck/prefix/test or /home/deck/prefix/test/

using the fix, change to
/home/deck/prefix/test/ or /home/deck/prefix/test

then save

config file will update to true path

my guess, something is causing a config scan/refresh when lutris loads game configs, but converts home directory to the relative path...

i only encountered this recently on the big feature update, so some recent commit might have caused the issue.

issue.title: Lutris Flatpak -- Disc "Autodetect" fails
issue.body:
### Bug description

This is really three different, but tangentially related issues:

Specific to Lutris Flatpak:

- Disc "Autodetect" fails for mounted disc image.

Not specific to Flatpak:

- If "Autodetect" fails, one can only press "Back". If one then presses "Continue" (second instance), the "Install or mount game disc [...]" dialogue does not re-appear as it should, but instead the install process tries to proceed with next steps, I.e. trying to copy files from `$DISC` path (which at this point is not set!).

Unsure if specific to Flatpak:

- "Eject" seems to simply eject the first available disc drive. This misses the mark in the case of multiple disc drives, or even mounted disc images, being present.

Aside: I tested the latest GitHub master and found the following:

- "Eject" causes Lutris to lock up (mind you, I'm running from within a toolbx/Podman environment).

- Disc "Autodetect" succeeds for mounted disc image.

### How to Reproduce

Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Mount a disc image.
2. Create a basic script with at least the following `installer` parameters: `insert-disc`, `merge`. Optionally: `insert-disc` -> `requires` should reference a non-existent file on said mounted disc (triggers second bug on non-Flatpak installs).
3. Run install script with Lutris Flatpak.
4. Press "Eject" and notice behaviour (third bug).
5. Try Disc "Autodetect". Notice it fails (first bug).
6. Press "Back", then "Continue". Notice that the "Install or mount game disc [...]" dialogue does not reappear, as it should (second bug). Instead, installer will attempt to `merge` the file from non-existent `$DISC` path.

### Expected behavior

1. Ideally, "Autodetect" should work within Flatpak, just like it does on a regular install. Else, it should disable "Autodetect" button and notify user of this limitation.

2. The "Install or mount game disc [...]" should reappear, thus maintaining the desired linear nature of the install process.

3. "Eject" button should have an associated drop-down button to specify a non-default drive/mounted disc image.

### Log output

```shell
# After pressing "Autodetect":

DEBUG    2023-10-25 13:57:16,946 [interpreter._iter_commands:349]:Installer command: {'insert-disc': {'requires': '<testfile.ext>'}}

# (Cont.) After pressing "Back", then "Continue":

DEBUG    2023-10-25 13:58:28,060 [commands.merge:272]:Merging $DISC/<testfile.ext> into <gamedir>
ERROR    2023-10-25 13:58:28,060 [errors.__init__:18]:Source does not exist: $DISC/<testfile.ext>
# [...]
```

comment.body:
I've put in a bunch more expansion code and I can now run a Wine game that I deliberately sabotaged with lots of ~.

So if you try the master branch now, you may find your games actually work. Let's hope!

commits.message:
Sprinkle os.path.expanduser all over

Yes, it's ugly and inelegant. But we've got many users with ~ in the paths in their config files.

This plops a bunch of expanduser calls in an effort to make games like that at least work.

It's unlikely this covers everything, but hopefully it will handle the most important cases.

commits.message:
Prophylactically expand ~ for wine prefix access.

It should be expanded, but just in case it is not.

Add exception handling so if desktop integration fails, the game may still be run.

The integration isn't critical; we'll log the exception and continue, and hope Wine can still start.

Resolves #5101

comment.body:
Well, the path it's trying to open is '~/Games/guild-wars-2/user.reg' and that is not really a valid path; the ~ thing needs to be expanded to get one. I do not understand why peoples libraries are growing these ~'s but you aren't the only one. Those paths are supposed to be expanded- '/home/ShadowJuubei/Games/guild-wars-2/user.reg'.

I can add code to expand the ~, and to survive errors here (the desktop integration isn't critical). But I expect that you'll have more problems with that ~ in there.

You might want to open the game config and update the game's directory or prefix or whatever is in there; you won't see the ~ there but if you can get it to resave it may fix this for you.

issue.title: Lutris Flatpak -- Disc "Autodetect" fails
issue.body:
### Bug description

This is really three different, but tangentially related issues:

Specific to Lutris Flatpak:

- Disc "Autodetect" fails for mounted disc image.

Not specific to Flatpak:

- If "Autodetect" fails, one can only press "Back". If one then presses "Continue" (second instance), the "Install or mount game disc [...]" dialogue does not re-appear as it should, but instead the install process tries to proceed with next steps, I.e. trying to copy files from `$DISC` path (which at this point is not set!).

Unsure if specific to Flatpak:

- "Eject" seems to simply eject the first available disc drive. This misses the mark in the case of multiple disc drives, or even mounted disc images, being present.

Aside: I tested the latest GitHub master and found the following:

- "Eject" causes Lutris to lock up (mind you, I'm running from within a toolbx/Podman environment).

- Disc "Autodetect" succeeds for mounted disc image.

### How to Reproduce

Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Mount a disc image.
2. Create a basic script with at least the following `installer` parameters: `insert-disc`, `merge`. Optionally: `insert-disc` -> `requires` should reference a non-existent file on said mounted disc (triggers second bug on non-Flatpak installs).
3. Run install script with Lutris Flatpak.
4. Press "Eject" and notice behaviour (third bug).
5. Try Disc "Autodetect". Notice it fails (first bug).
6. Press "Back", then "Continue". Notice that the "Install or mount game disc [...]" dialogue does not reappear, as it should (second bug). Instead, installer will attempt to `merge` the file from non-existent `$DISC` path.

### Expected behavior

1. Ideally, "Autodetect" should work within Flatpak, just like it does on a regular install. Else, it should disable "Autodetect" button and notify user of this limitation.

2. The "Install or mount game disc [...]" should reappear, thus maintaining the desired linear nature of the install process.

3. "Eject" button should have an associated drop-down button to specify a non-default drive/mounted disc image.

### Log output

```shell
# After pressing "Autodetect":

DEBUG    2023-10-25 13:57:16,946 [interpreter._iter_commands:349]:Installer command: {'insert-disc': {'requires': '<testfile.ext>'}}

# (Cont.) After pressing "Back", then "Continue":

DEBUG    2023-10-25 13:58:28,015 [installerwindow.on_extras_ready:562]:Installer doesn't require files
DEBUG    2023-10-25 13:58:28,016 [interpreter._iter_commands:349]:Installer command: {'merge': {'src': '$DISC/<testfile.ext>', 'dst': '$GAMEDIR/drive_c'}}
DEBUG    2023-10-25 13:58:28,060 [commands.merge:272]:Merging $DISC/<testfile.ext> into <gamedir>
ERROR    2023-10-25 13:58:28,060 [errors.__init__:18]:Source does not exist: $DISC/<testfile.ext>
# [...]
```


### System Information

```shell

Desktop:         GNOME
```

Hmm, this is a bit non-obvious, but this sort of issue is often due to an exception somewhere awkward not being handled as it needs to be.

Perhaps you could post the rest of the debug log; I would expect a trace-back in there somewhere.

Thought I am pretty sure Lutris is not smart enough to figure out which disc to eject in any case.

commits.message: Added support for Flatpak custom commands (#5090)

pull_request.title: Added support for Flatpak custom commands
pull_request.body: I noticed the flatpak runner allowed setting the --command variable, it didn't use that variable for anything. It wasn't needed for most games, but some flatpaks (like OpenRA) utilize that to launch different apps. I changed the variable to fcommand to avoid confusion and linked it up where needed. I tested it with and without the variable. It works like it did before if the variable isn't set and it honors the variable now if it is set.

issue.title: Weird Lutris' behaviour when launching Steam games.
issue.body:
### Bug description

There are two scenarios:
- when Steam is already running on game launch
- when Luris launches Steam on game launch

In first scenario, when I lauch a game while Steam is already running, Lutris terminates processes related the game launch only after few seconds from launch, although the game itself is in an early stage of launch (processing vulkan shaders, etc.).

In the second scenario, when Steam is not running at the game launch, Lutris opens Steam, processes don't terminate and game time is being calculated properly, but to actually return to Lutris after exiting the game, Steam needs to be closed manually. Also, sometimes game needs to be stopped in Lutris UI (by pressing Stop button) even if Steam is not running anymore.

### How to Reproduce

1st scenario
1. Launch Steam.
2. Launch Lutris with $ lutris -d.
3. Launch any Steam game from within Lutris.
4. See Lutris stops monitoring launched game after just few seconds.

2nd scenario:
1. Launch Lutris with $ lutris -d.
2. Launch any Steam game from within Lutris.
3. See Lutris not closing Steam after exiting the game.
4. Witness Lutris not stopping game related processes even after closing Steam (only sometimes).


### Expected behavior

1st scenario:
Keep monitoring the game until player exits it (properly calculating time spent playing the game).

2nd scenario:
Lutris closes Steam automatically after exiting the game, and closes all game realted processes (without a need to press Stop).

### Log output

------- This is log info with Steam runing prior to game launch:

[pastebin log 1](https://pastebin.com/NgRpacKH)

------- And This is log info with Steam not runing prior to game launch:

[pastebin log 2](https://pastebin.com/ViEPUGGh)

Sorry for pastebin but I was having "message too long" error from GitHub.

issue.title: [Feature request] Provide a way to reinstall/update GoG games
issue.body:
A number of games on GoG do not release updates via separate update files but instead by replacing the game installer file with the new version. At the moment this means if you want to update one of the games that does this you have two options:

1.) Remove the entire game including whatever saves/profiles may be present and go through the installation process again (optionally backing up any game data you might still want/need).

2.) Update the game manually by downloading and running the new installer, pointing it to wherever your game is currently installed.

It would be nice if we were given a "reinstall" option or if the update option allowed you to select the installer in addition to whatever update files might be available.

comment.body:
Ok, so it is very similar to the Cyberpunk situation indeed. 

I found out that there is a way to update and manage GOG games installed with Lutris in GOG Galaxy. 
Once you have installed Galaxy, you can detect installed games. Point the GOG scanner to the prefix of the game you want to update and it should find it. (It should be located in the Z: drive from Wine's perspective)

This is a nice workaround to wait for a better implementation in Lutris
